 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = a^{kx}$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = cos(x)$,

If $y = tan(x)$,

Chain Rule: 
 
 If $y = y(u(x))$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

Product Rule: If $y = u v$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

Quotient Rule: If $\displaystyle y = \frac{u}{v}$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $\displaystyle \frac{dx}{dy}$ is known, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = cosec(x)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = sec(x)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = cot(x)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = cos^{-1}(x)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

If $y = tan^{-1}(x)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

Parametric: If $x = x(t)$ and $y = y(t)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = $ ?

Implicit: If $y$ is defined implicitly by $f(y)$, 
 
 then $\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}(f(y)) = $ ?
How to determine the nature of a stationary point, where $f'(a) = 0$?

back.content:
- If $f''(a) > 0$: it is a local minimum.
- If $f''(a) < 0$: it is a local maximum.
- If $f''(a) = 0$: you cannot tell, so: 

- Test $f''(a-h)$ and $f''(a+h)$ for a small value, $h$:

- If both $> 0$: local minimum.
- If both $< 0$: local maximum.
- If they change sign: point of inflection.

Which UK city has the hottest total mean and daily mean temperatures?
Which UK city has the coldest total mean temperature?
Which worldwide city has the hottest total mean temperature?
Which worldwide city has the hottest daily mean temperature?
Which worldwide city has the coldest total mean temperature and why?

back.content:
Perth, Australia

Because the data covers May to October, excluding Australia's summer months since it is in the southern hemisphere.

front.content: Which is the windiest month in the UK?
When did the Great Storm occur and how can we see this in the data?

back.content:
October 1987

The data shows a significant spike in total rainfall for that month, with a peak of 238.5mm in total in Heathrow.

front.content: In the UK, are coastal or inland areas generally more windy?

back.content: Coastal areas are generally more windy than inland areas.

front.content:
Where are these locations on a map:

 Cambourne, Heathrow, Hurn, Leeming, Leuchars, Beijing, Jacksonville, Perth

Daily Mean Temperature (0900-0900):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, (approx.) range (UK/worldwide), skew and note?

back.content:
Description: Mean air temperature in a 24-hour period between 0900 and 0900 GMT.
Units: Degrees Celsius [°C]
Data Type: Real number rounded to 1 d.p.; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: Worldwide
Range UK: 3.8°C (Leuchars, May-Oct 2015) to 28.7°C (Heathrow, May-Oct 2015)
Range Worldwide: 2.9°C (Beijing, May-Oct 1987) to 32.5°C (Beijing, May-Oct 2015)
Skew: Symmetric (normally distributed)
Note: Around 0.5°C warmer in 2015 than 1987.

front.content:
Daily Total Rainfall (0900-0900):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, (approx.) range (UK/worldwide), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Total rainfall in a 24-hour period from 0900 to 0900 GMT.
Units: Millimetres [mm]
Data Type: Real number rounded to 1 d.p.; 'tr' means trace (<0.05mm); 'n/a' means not available. Clean by removing 'n/a' and setting 'tr' to 0.0mm.
Scope: Worldwide
Range UK: 'tr' to 53.1mm (Heathrow, May-Oct 1987)
Range Worldwide: 'tr' to 104.0mm (Perth, May-Oct 1987)
Skew: Strongly positive (long right tail)

front.content:
Daily Total Sunshine (0000-2400):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, range (UK), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Duration where brightness is above a threshold in a 24-hour period from 0000 to 2400 GMT.
Units: Hours [h]
Data Type: Real number rounded to 1 d.p.; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: UK only
Range UK: 0 to 15.9h (Leuchars, May-Oct 2015)
Skew: Symmetric (normally distributed)

front.content:
Daily Mean Windspeed (0000-2400):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, (approx.) range (UK/worldwide), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Mean wind speed in a 24-hour period from 0000 to 2400 GMT.
Units: Knots [kn] (1 kn ≈ 0.514 m/s)
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest whole number (UK), or to 1 d.p. (Overseas); 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: Worldwide
Range UK: 1 kn (Leeming, May-Oct 1987) to 23 kn (Leuchars, May-Oct 2015)
Range Worldwide: 0.2 kn (Perth, May-Oct 1987) to 23 kn (Leuchars, May-Oct 2015)
Skew: Moderately positive (long right tail)
Note: Coastal cities tend to be windier than inland cities.

front.content:
Daily Mean Windspeed (Beaufort conversion):

What are the description, units, data type, and scope?

back.content:
Description: Mean wind speed in a 24-hour period from 0000 to 2400 GMT, categorised using the Beaufort scale.
Units: None
Data Type: Qualitative: 'Light', 'Fresh', 'Moderate', 'Strong'; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: Worldwide

front.content:
Daily Maximum Gust (0000-2400):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, range (UK), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Maximum gust of wind in a 24-hour period from 0000 to 2400 GMT.
Units: Knots [kn]
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest whole number; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: UK only
Range UK: 7 kn (Leuchars, May-Oct 1987) to 78 kn (Cambourne, May-Oct 2015)
Skew: Strongly positive (long right tail)

front.content:
Daily Maximum Relative Humidity:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, range (UK), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Maximum relative humidity in a 24-hour period from 0000 to 2400 GMT. Relative humidity is the amount of water in the air as a percentage of the maximum the air can hold at that temperature. Values above 95% are associated with mist and fog.
Units: None
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest whole number; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: UK only
Range UK: 65% (Heathrow, May-Oct 2015) to 100%
Skew: Strongly negative (long left tail)

front.content:
Daily Mean Total Cloud:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, and skew?

back.content:
Description: Mean total cloud cover in a 24-hour period.
Units: Oktas (eighths of the sky covered by cloud)
Data Type: Integer from 0 to 8; 'n/a' means not available.
Scope: UK only
Skew: Symmetric (normally distributed)

front.content:
Daily Mean Visibility:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, range (UK), and skew?

back.content:
Description: The mean greatest horizontal distance at which an object can be seen and recognised in daylight.
Units: Decametres [dam] (1 dam = 10 m)
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest hundred; dash indicates data not available.
Scope: UK only
Range UK: 0 dam (Camborne, May-Oct 1987) to 6300 dam (Camborne, May-Oct 1987)
Skew: Weakly positive (long right tail)

front.content:
Daily Mean Pressure:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, mean, (approx.) range (UK/worldwide), and skew?

back.content:
Description: Mean pressure at sea level in a 24-hour period.
Units: Hectopascals [hPa] (1 hPa = 100 Pa)
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest whole number.
Scope: Worldwide
Mean: 1000 hPa
Range UK: 976 hPa (Leuchars, May-Oct 1987) to 1036 hPa (Camborne, May-Oct 1987)
Range Worldwide: 976 hPa (Leuchars, May-Oct 1987) to 1036 hPa (Camborne, May-Oct 1987)
Skew: Moderately negative (long left tail)

front.content:
Daily Mean Wind Direction:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, and care?

back.content:
Description: Mean wind direction in a 24-hour period, measured clockwise from north.
Units: Degrees [°]
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest ten.
Scope: UK only
Care: This is the direction the wind is coming from, not the direction it is going.

front.content:
Cardinal Direction (of the Daily Mean Wind Direction):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, and care?

back.content:
Description: Mean Daily Wind Direction categorised into cardinal directions.
Units: None
Data Type: Qualitative: 'N', 'NNE', 'NE', 'ENE', 'E', 'ESE', 'SE', 'SSE', 'S', 'SSW', 'SW', 'WSW', 'W', 'WNW', 'NW', or 'NNW'.
Scope: UK only
Care: This is the direction the wind is coming from, not the direction it is going.

front.content:
Daily Max Gust Corresponding Direction:

What are the description, units, data type, scope, and care?

back.content:
Description: Direction of the maximum gust of wind in a 24-hour period, measured clockwise from north.
Units: Degrees [°]
Data Type: Real number rounded to nearest ten.
Scope: UK only
Care: This is the direction the wind is coming from, not the direction it is going.

front.content:
Cardinal Direction (of the Daily Max Gust Corresponding Direction):

What are the description, units, data type, scope, and care?

back.content:
Description: Daily Max Gust Corresponding Direction, categorised into cardinal directions.
Units: None
Data Type: Qualitative: 'N', 'NNE', 'NE', 'ENE', 'E', 'ESE', 'SE', 'SSE', 'S', 'SSW', 'SW', 'WSW', 'W', 'WNW', 'NW', or 'NNW'.
Scope: UK only
Care: This is the direction the wind is coming from, not the direction it is going.

front.content: test
Equation for the Mean of Grouped Data

back.content:
Mean = $\displaystyle \frac{Σf x}{Σf}$,

where f = frequency and x = midpoint of class

front.content: What does a function do?

back.content: A function maps each element of a set (the domain) to exactly one element of another set (the range).

front.content:
Which of the following types of mappings can be expressed as a function?

One-to-one
Many-to-one
One-to-many
Many-to-many

back.content:
One-to-one - Yes ✅
Many-to-one - Yes ✅
One-to-many - No ❌
Many-to-many - No ❌

front.content: What to do to a many-to-one function before its inverse can be found?

back.content: Restrict its domain so that it becomes a one-to-one function.

front.content: Once the inverse of a function has been found, what to remember? (2)

back.content:
1) That the range of the inverse matches the domain of the original function by restricting any $\pm$ signs to $+$ or $-$.

2) That domain is restricted to prevent undefined values due to divide by zero errors.

front.content: Method for projectiles, A & B, colliding in 2D?

back.content:
$\large{\textbf{r}}_{\small{A}} = \textbf{r}_{\small{B}}$

where $\large{\textbf{r}}=\large{\textbf{r}}_0+\large{\textbf{s}}$

where:
$\large{\textbf{r}}$ is the position vector at time t,
$\large{\textbf{r}}_0$ is the initial position vector, and
$\large{\textbf{s}}$ is the displacement vector at time t.
